Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Software system that streams data from flight data recorders in aerial vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable the aviation businesses to capture and analyze flight data in real-time for increased efficiency and profits. Flight data recorders were first put into use in 1947. They have since evolved into valuable tools for monitoring all aspects of flight. Today, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandates the recording of 88 parameters; Some operators are recording up to 2,000 additional parameters. Current solutions to the challenges of real-time data acquisition entail high satellite transmission costs and additional capital equipment requirements. Therefore, commercial airlines continue using post-flight data analysis, while many operators forego utilizing flight data altogether. The proposed technology intends to change this scenario by offering a software solution that can reside in equipment aboard an aircraft, transmitting data using low-cost transmission methods. The technology may encourage wider use of flight data and enable participation in Flight Operations Quality Assurance (FOQA) programs. If a disaster happens at sea or over difficult terrain, the proposed system could render expensive recovery operations obsolete since all flight data recorder data would be available in the cloud.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project provides real-time data acquisition for ground-based monitoring of flights, allowing for engine data and pilot control inputs to be analyzed while an aircraft is in the air. Currently, most flight recorder data are only analyzed days or weeks after a flight, when the opportunity to address cost-saving efficiency and safety issues is long past. With the proposed technology, flight crews and maintenance teams would be able to make flight and safety adjustments based on streaming data in real time. In addition, the new technology would encourage data mining in the aviation industry to enhance aircraft performance, conserve resources, protect the environment, and improve safety. The system runs on an aircraft server and distributed main and data servers. The mode of transmission can be radio, cellular links, satellite, or via other, emerging technology such as high-altitude blimps. The amount and rate of data and the time window are highly predictable, thus resulting in efficient planning of resources.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I-Corps: Software system that streams data from flight data recorders in aerial vehicles

 

Project Outcomes Report

Dr. Junaid Zubairi

This award provided an opportunity for ZubAir to explore the various ways in which the aviation industry currently uses and handles flight data and its analysis. We were especially interested in learning how the FOQA (Flight Operations Quality Assurance) managers deal with the operational readiness of planes and what role is played by flight data systems in real-time and offline decisions. We also wanted to know about the limitations of current aviation technologies in avoiding failures and problems.

ZubAir conducted interviews of over 100 industry professionals. They included FDR/FDM manufacturer, FAA investigator, data communications provider, Aerospace Engineer and pilot aong others. The NSF I-Corps award allowed us to explore the aviation data technologies and see if there was a gap that could be bridged using the Flight Data Tracker. We also learned about the plane tracking technologies including ADSB and QAR and the proposed initiative to provide connectivity to the commercial aviation sector using VLEO satellites. We also noticed that flight operational data in limited quantities is currently being transferred using satellite link. In one of the interviews, GE Aviation team mentioned that four snapshots of data are transferred per flight to the ground, keeping the communication cost down. We came to know that with the modern planes using state of the art technologies, the risk of failures and crashes has been minimized. However, the operational readiness of long-haul flights and the planes of regional airlines and fleets could potentially benefit from the streaming of flight data in real-time. We got very encouraging responses from some companies. In a follow-up interview with RTI (Real-Time Innovations), Sunnyvale California, we were offered an opportunity to integrate the FDT with the RTI DDS (Data Distribution Service) Connext. This is a real-time data transfer system that is currently being used in US Navy ships, NASA robots, drone ground control stations and Aurora flight sciences robotic copilot. RTI offered their product licenses to us for test and development. We defined specific flight data under different topics and using the RTI DDS publisher-subscriber model, we were able to transmit and receive the data on different hosts, with reliability QoS attached to most critical data. Next target was to test the encryption and authentication feature offered by RTI DDS Connext. It was also accomplished successfully. It is a significant achievement given the fact that DDS Connext publishes the data by topic and many industry professionals expressed interest in receiving and processing specific flight data instead of full data. RTI?s reliability and data range feature was also tested and found suitable for ZubAir functionality.

The news of our collaboration with RTI was carried by the aviation industry publications and it reached the NTSB (National Transportation Safety Board), a federal government agency charged with ensuring transportation safety. NTSB contacted us and requested us to explain the technology to their experts. Several experts of NTSB participated in the online presentation on June 8, 2021. NTSB does not endorse any technologies developed by private companies however they are always looking to learn about the new developments.

We learned that the new Boeing planes, including the 787 dreamliner, have replaced multiple modules and computers with CCS (Common Core System) from GE. CCS runs on VxWorks, a real-time operating system from WindRiver, a company based in California. This sparked our interest in testing the ZubAir system on embedded systems. Under the I-Corps program, we requested and got approval for R&D for experimenting to integrate ZubAir with RTI DDS Connext over VxWorks. We contacted WindRiver and submitted a proposal to use VxWorks in our research. WindRiver approved our proposal and provided two licenses to us for VxWorks RTOS. Currently, we are working to configure and run ZubAir on an embedded system using VxWorks. The target is to build a reliable, secure and flexible real-time flight data platform that can provide the opportunities for the aviation industry to benefit from the data in optimizing and securing their operations.
